comments.commentBody: Blaming the victim has always been a useful defense against responsibility to help right things that are clearly wrong. (Also useful defense against helplessness/hopelessness, as well as survivor's guilt, when people experience mysterious, huge forces way beyond their control, such as natural disasters, plagues, etc. - but that's another story).

I'm glad I introduced you to Andy Varipapa, John.

Luckily he wasn't a cricketer, Leapy.
You picked a great one.

I knew you'd pick up on that, suejean.

Apart from any relevant Python skits, we'd watch cricket matches at nearby Lower Canada College in Montreal.

I agree with Deb about the puzzle.

But my avatar is even harder to uncover. Not even Martin will get this one. But it is Saturday and therefore not easy.
I should have GEIST that people would still be INURN'd.

Hi Allen,

Welcome to Wordplay!

You mean something like this?
That’s the ticket!
I would have preferred PUMPSITUP.

'Despite freedom of the press, the press is not free to advocate violence or crime, nor to lie with malice even against public figures."

Quick... someone tell Fox the News.

This comment is as elegant as it is succinct. I think the vast majority of gun owners share this sentiment and would support reasonable controls based on this clear and pragmatic approach. It's a pity someone with this much common sense has the good sense not to run for public office. Thanks Mark.

"The question buried in the harangue was whether she could imagine listing exceptions to other parts of the Bill of Rights."

All of our rights have exceptions. Despite freedom of religion, Mormons had to give up multiple wives, and others had to allow medical care for their kids, and nobody could use serious crimes as religious rites. Despite freedom of the press, the press is not free to advocate violence or crime, nor to lie with malice even against public figures. Every right however treasured has exceptions.

Furthermore, rights tend to conflict with each other, because they are absolutes. Much of Constitutional Law is balancing the conflicts between rights.

What Cruz said was beyond ignorant. He's a lawyer and does know better, and he was playing others for fools with pure bombast. He was doing that in a room full of people who know better, playing to an audience not even there.

I support all of our rights, including gun rights, and proper balancing of all of them by reasonable regulation such as that expressly allowed in the recent case law correctly establishing that the right to keep and bear arms is a personal right. It is not a right to fire weapons in populated areas, nor to keep and bear bazookas or RPGs.

While I think about it, or not, here's an article about Alan Page that's interesting.
http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/110405aah.html

I've got to get back to this ball on my nose.

It's long overdue that criminal malfeasance on wall street is met with stiff prison sentences.
Now that the turmoil of the last 6 years is beginning to subside, it's appropriate that individuals and institutions guilty of criminal financial acts leading to the meltdown of our economy - in insurance, appraisal, lending and banking, etc. be brought to justice. Jaime Dimon and his ilk deserve nothing less.
Yes, Martin, that is an interesting article.

All good things must come to an end. Even in the beginning, the Big East was not like the SEC or ACC. It didn't have the history of the PAC10, or 12 or whatever it is now, or what was the Big 10. (Wasn't it originally 8?) What it had is just what Bill said it had. Great match ups, great players and telegenic coaches. I won't miss it, so goodbye Big East! At least Dave Gavitt has passed on so he doesn't have to see its end.

I don't know why the NBA and the NFL don't have an entry level league of their own where they can groom players and weed out those who aspire to play in the bigs but just don't possess that certain something gifted others have.

Colleges and universities should be about higher education, as they were intended, and not a showcase for football and basketball scouts.

How about some research about what happens to the rejects. How many that do make the bigs, how long they last? Career lengths. Jobs they ultimately end up having, etc., etc.
There are lots of teams that do. Thunder, Nuggets, Celtics, Grizzlies, and the Heat all emphasize the team play.

Though I live in San Antonio, I don't follow pro basketball.  One of the attributes of Coach Pop is his ability to get his players to check their egos at the door and to believe in the value of the team.  Maybe other teams in the league should consider adopting his methods.

Like prices ever go down? Had season tix for the Rangers from 1984-96 and sat in the blue seats. Game 7 of the SC finals cost $25. With each renovation, more and more cheap seats are lopped off. It will eventually become corporate and tourists attending game, with a small minority of diehard fans. But this is what the league and owners want, people with a few hundred bucks to drop at each game.
(Also - nice red buttons, guys).
They can play slow - that is not for the faint of heart.

I cannot agree more with Mr. Reinhardt's comment regarding gun ownership and the healthcare system in the USA. Neither makes the slightest sense.

How industry propagandists and industry legislators in the USA Congress get away with non-stop and evermore egregious lying about anything related to either issue is beyond me.

I recommend that any interested commenter read the report of the commission with which Mr. Reinhard was involved. I read it when it was issued. It is outstanding and very enlightening.

Rockyboy,

LBJ doesn't belong in your list. He fought like a tiger for The Civil Rights Act of 1964, and The Great Society brought us Medicare, Medicaid, Federal Aid for Education. He had compassion and empathy for those struggling with segregation and poverty.

His achievements truly laid the foundation for today's more democratic America.

Think about it. There's no shortage of people who are an embarrassment to their distinguished alma maters. So maybe we shouldn't hold the institutions themselves in the high regard we do. They've graduated some pretty repellent people, many of whom sit on our highest courts and teach at our finest law schools.

So, if a guy challenges a doddering old fool, that's sexist if the fool is female? I was shocked at her incompetence. Shocked, I tell you. Did you watch the interaction?  If women want to rise to the highest levels, crying sexism won't get them there. Cruz is a brilliant lawyer.

Ted Cruz is an embarrassment to himself and to the voters of Texas. He's an embarrassment to Princeton University and Harvard Law School. Every time he opens his mouth his foot goes further in. And he seems oblivious. Rude and sexist. Is there some hidden side to him that's better than what he's chosen to display in public?

Unbelievable.
As long as Mr. Gensler  is available to stall on the implementation of Dodd-Frank --nothing will happen...Senate refuses to confirm  Mr. Codray head of the SEC..  So sad!!

It's safe to assume you're a music teacher then, Prof?

How's that Mumbai stock exchange going? SEBI's really showing the crooks who's boss, aren't they?

Did you read the article above, or are you just coming on here to spout some rubbish?
Can you say 'jail time?'  When these organizations pay a fine, it doesn't come out of their personal accounts.  Jail time, extensive, is the answer.

Was the Federal Securities Exchange Commission created only to impose penalties on financial frauds and recover paltry sums of money on that count, or to prevent the malpractices like insider trading, rate rigging or similar financial market manipulations at the Wall Street casino?

Social Security will be shown up as the Ponzi scheme it is when:

1. The US disintegrates as a political entity and/or
2. The government loses the ability to collect taxes.

Someone want to tell me when that's going to happen?

Until then, its problems are relatively easily fixed.

Not quite. Social Security is a forced savings plan with a big insurance policy against low earnings (as it should be). And the insurance premiums are 'paid' by the wealthy (as they should be).

In fact, high-income and single people get back considerably less than they've contributed (in current-money present-value terms).

'Removing the cap' would make it worse for wealthy people because of the way benefits are figured.

I really like my Tivo Premier but their pricing model is not friendly at all to existing customers.  I upgraded from a Tivo Series 2 and had to have two subscriptions active even though the Series 2 no longer worked with my cable system.  I would upgrade to the new 4 tuner model but that would mean I would be paying for two subscriptions again.  No thanks.  The sad part is even with the +$6 subscription(for the Mini it is still cheaper monthly then a Xfinity multiroom setup.
(Also - nice red buttons, guys).

Medicare taxes and premiums don't pay anywhere near the cost of medicare - and they were never intended to. Most of Medicare is and always was funded by transfers from the general fund.

Social Security is different, it's intended to be paid out of a dedicated tax stream. And it could continue to be, with a few tweaks. However, what each individual pays into and gets out of Social Security in general doesn't balance.

As I said, Social Security will be a Ponzi scheme when the US government can no longer collect taxes to fund it. Someone tell me when that will be.

I lost my 10 year old kitty in September. Never sick a day in her life, she fell over and hubby rushed her to the vet. He did tests and send results to a cardiologist, and there was something wrong with her heart. I took off the next day from work, brought her in to the hospital, and he recommended a pacemaker. It cost a lot of money, and I took her home and she died 4 days later of perhaps a blood clot. Would I do it again? No. It was traumatic for her, unbeknownst to us, she'd need medications every day - which she fought with screeches and flailing around horribly. I should have taken the advice of my regular vet and just kept her at home, held her, and let her die at home with me. It's not worth the pain and horror to put an animal through this. In fact, I do not even want to go through this. Do I think the cardiologist did the wrong thing? Yes. Is it his fault, having put pacemakers in lots of animals before? No. But based on the puny size of my kitty, and the huge size of the human pacemaker, I believe it was as poor recommendation. It's a tough call, when you - as the "parent" are put on the spot to make a life and death decision. I grieve every day. But this is life, and we move on.

To the ‘Lens’ blog writers, photographers, contributors, and even NYT editors… I wonder if a subject such as this that is highlighted in this series, that garners only 2 commentsis is dismaying to you all.

An inconsequential to the reality of the worlds people article on the NYT digital format regarding ‘Lance Armstrong’ and ‘doping’ in professional cycling completion generates many hundreds of comments. And this more relevant and important (to me anyway) subject matter generates only 2 comments… even though for a while this ‘Lens’ article appeared on the ‘home page’ of the NYT.

American idols, and especially its ‘fallen idols’ are obviously more important to and relevant to the NYT commentariat.

In the meantime… Rome and the world is on fire.

Anyway, I appreciate and look forward to ‘Lens’ installments… no matter what the subject or issue is.

If the reason for the question was to be able to trend, for equity why not add the question framed for fathers and start comparing the responses over time? Their response indicates they were focused more on trends than on the supposed concept of the survey.
Kudos to President Obama for refusing to continue the absurd dance of North Korean threats followed by Western aid.
